title: Did the common people who lived during the Renaissance period know and understand that they were in a Renaissance period? - Quora

response.answer_text: While the educated and ruling classes probably had an notion of change in the air, we rarely recognize change while we are undergoing it. Think about growing old - one day we wake up and notice the gray hairs, or the wrinkles or whatever, but we are not aware of it in the moment. The common people had even less reason to concern themselves with Renaissance or any other changes in art, literature, philosophy.  As Thomas Hobbes put it (though he was writing about a society with no government): Life would be nasty, brutish and short. For the common man it was a struggle to stay alive and feed the family. Only after some of the great works of the Renaissance were completed, and their creators gone, was their a recognition of the wonderous change that was wrought.

Have in  mind common people was far away from the main and first manifestations of the Renaissance: Academia, fine arts. Architecture was the most evident. But, when you analyze the stile in the previous centuries, you see changes from time to time.Until 19th century, consciousness of living a special age almost didn't existed. May be the last previous moment in history was year 1000, when doomsday didn't happen, and Gothic cathedrals and churches became the signal of gratitude from christian Europeans for their survival.

Depends on what you define as common people. Most of them would be too busy surviving difficult unsanitary conditions and fighting against illnesses, trying to keep their offspring alive to notice there was a "Renaissance" out there
